conbody.note: The content of this section is only relevant for NCC-VNF.

section.p: The CDRs generated are ASN.1 encoded and are saved as binary files. You can use a decoding tool to decode to plain text files. NCC provides a CDR decoding tool, which can be accessed through the command line. The tool is available in the RPM package csf-cdr-tool-1.0.rpm. Using it, you can decode one file at a time.
section.sectiondiv:
Run cdrdecoding
As root user, use the following commands to move to the appropriate directory and then run the command:cd /opt/csf-cdr-tool/bin./cdrdecoding -f <encoded CDR file> -a <Appname> -c <cdrsettype> -o <DATA / HEADER>Where,
-f Input encoded CDR file
-c CDR set type is generic,cdrsettype1
-a App name can be: generic record (for generic cdrset); ocsrecord (for cdrsettype1)
-0 Two option are possible: HDR (header of file); DATA (data of file)
Example:./cdrdecoding -f /cdr/default/"_-_16.20170703_-_0529+0000.cdr" -a ocsrecord -c cdrsettype1 -o DATA
The decoded CDR file is generated with a .out extension at the same location where the encoded file is present (as specified in the -f option in the command). In the above example, the output file is named as _-_16.20170703_-_0529+0000.out and is available at /cdr/default/.
